body.p:
To his Excellency B. Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky

The petitioner William McClanahan repectfully represents to your Excellency, that in the summer of 1862 Robert H. Shepperd came home from the South, where he has resided for some years. While in Mason County, he became intoxicated in Company with a party of young men, and was charged with passing two Counterfeit half dollars. was taken up and tried by the mayor of the City of Maysville, and placed in jail in default of Three Hundred dollars bail. after he was placed in jail, and became sober he stated that he knew nothing of having or knowing any conterfeit coin, that if he had done so, he knew nothing about it, and had received the coin when drunk. He was in jail, his family consisting of his wife and two daughters, were neighbors of mine. He had worked with and for me and had resided in my family, a liberal and naturally a kind hearted man himself. I yielded to the importunities of his wife and became his bondsman. He promised to return I am informed that the would have done so but he while on a spree, got beyond the lines of the two armies and could not
get back The grand jury indicted him in October 1861 and the Attorney for the State filed the indictment away in April His recognizance was forfeited and judgt given against me for Three Hundred dollars and the costs as his bondsman, To pay this sum will amost ruin me at this time I therefore petition your Excellency to remit so much of the judgment against me an your Excellency has power to remit

The Undersigned know William McCLanahan and are familiar with the facts of his Case. We join him in his petition and request Gov Magoffin to release him from the payment of the judgment against him April 22d 1862

T. C Campbell
Jno M Duke Jr
Jno D Taylor
Goe. W. Sulser.
I G Hickman
Jno R Clarke
E Whitaker
W H Savage
H. Taylor
I knew W Shepard and I am well acquainted with Mr. William McClannahan

I have no doubt Mr. McClannahan became the bail of Shepard from the best of motives, the payment of the bail will be oppresive to M. McClannahan and that it will be proper to remit a large portion of the judgment

I know nothing of the facts of this case or of the party against whom the recognizance was forfeited, but I know Mr McClannahn to be a gentleman, & have no doubt his representations of the facts are true, & that he ought to be relieved by the interposition of executive clemency

Mason Cir Ct
$300 } Recog
McClannahan & Sheppard
Remission issd May. 1. 1862
